description: UMD 2.7.0 is the 9th update of second Major release of UMD (Unified Middleware Distribution) made available for the EGI production infrastructure. This release supports both Scientific Linux 5 and 6.
releaseNotes: <div>This release contains the following products:</div><div><b>EMI Technology Provider:</b></div><div>Job Execution services:</div><div>CREAM-GE 2.0.2 release in SL5 and SL6:</div><div><ul><li>This is a bugfix release which solves some issues in both glite-info-dynamic-ge and the glite-yaim-ge-utils.</li></ul></div><div>Information Discovery:</div><div>BDII-TOP released in SL5 and SL6:</div><div><ul><li>This version provide a bug fixes for the information provider on which the ldap queries were failing to get GLUE 2 Contact and Location information from site BDIIs together with a fix for the slow performance. The release also contains a minor fix in the glite-info-plugin-delayed-delete-status plugin.</li></ul></div><div>BDII-CORE released in SL5 and SL6</div><div><ul><li>This version provide a bug fixes &nbsp;for a hardcoded path affecting ARC installations. Also presente is a new version of glue-validator containing a series of improvements and a new command line.</li></ul></div><div>Storage Management:</div><br/><div>DPM 1.8.6-3 released in SL5 and SL6:</div><div><ul><li>This is a small release with an update of dpm-xrootd which &nbsp;now requires XRootD 3.3.x. This update is only needed if you have previously installed dpm-xrootd and so dpm-xrootd is not installed as a part of DPM by default.</li></ul></div><div>IGE Technology Provider:</div><br/><div>Globus-gsissh 5.3.9 released only in SL6:</div><div><ul><li>This is a very minimal release, covering one security vulnerabilities recently reported. No new functionality has been introduced.<br></li></ul></div><br/>
installationNotes: All products in the UMD 2.7.0 release were verified against EGI's current Quality Criteria (for further information, please see the documentation links) to support 64 bit Scientific Linux 5 and Scientific Linux 6 (x86_64 processor architecture). Some products are also supported in 64 bit Debian 6 (squeeze). &nbsp;Installation and configuration notes are available in the EGI repository.
contact: For further information about the UMD, its goals and surrounding processes, and more information about how to engage as a Technology Provider with EGI, please send an Email to: cto (at) egi.eu.
technicalContact: For any bugs and issues you encounter that are not described in the release notes of this UMD release, or the related documentation provided by the Technology Providers, please visit the EGI Helpdesk to make a report.
knownIssues: <div>Details containing known issues and workarounds found in EGI verification and staged rollout are collected in:&nbsp;<a href="https://wiki.egi.eu/wiki/UMD-2:UMD-2.7.0">https://wiki.egi.eu/wiki/UMD-2:UMD-2.7.0</a></div>
changeLog: <div>This releases includes updates for the following products:</div><div><ul><li>BDII-TOP<br></li><li>BDII-CORE<br></li><li>DPM<br></li><li>GSISSH<br></li><li>CREAM-GE<br></li></ul></div>

products.name: emi.bdii-core
products.description: The Berkeley Database Information Index (BDII) consists of a standard LDAP database which is updated by an external process. The update process obtains LDIF from a number of sources and merges them. It then compares this to the contents of the database and creates an LDIF file of the differences. This is then used to update the database.
products.releaseNotes:
This new version of the site BDII contains a fix in the ldap info provider script to set to 'Unknown' cached GLUE state attributes

Bug fixes:

BUG #101709: Set to 'Unknown' ldap info provider cached state attributes for the site BDII

products.name: emi.dpm
products.description: The Disk Pool Manager (DPM) is a lightweight storage solution for grid sites. It offers a simple way to create a disk-based grid storage element and supports relevant protocols (SRM, gridFTP, RFIO) for file management and access. It focus on manageability (ease of installation, configuration, low effort of maintenance), while providing all required functionality for a grid storage solution (support for multiple disk server nodes, different space types, multiple file replicas in disk pools).
